trustfund: TF029455-PHRD-PARTNERSHIP IN FAMILY DEV. FOR,TF030307-CANADIAN (GEN) CTF FY03 - HIV AIDS,TF032093-INDONESIA - HEALTH

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, and likely sustainability, but institutional
            development impacts were modest. The project experience
            re-emphasizes the importance of clear strategies and
            technical know-how upon decentralization, as well as the
            critical aspects of adapting the project design to the local
            implementation capacity. In the Indonesian context, the
            long-term success of the integrated safe motherhood program
            will require a clear resolution of the issues of cooperation
            between the National Family Planning Coordinating Board
            (BKKBN) and the Ministry of Health (MOH). Coordination
            meetings and workshops, even planning mechanisms may not be
            enough, if stronger incentives for coordination are not in
            place. Moreover, coordination at the local level is simpler,
            and most likely to succeed as has been noted. Using vouchers
            as a tool for demand-side financing is logistically
            feasible, and would be an effective way to target the poor.
            Despite the limited scope of the pilots, these clearly
            demonstrated the possible use of vouchers, and such demand
            financing tools to help improve access to services. This
            model can also be adapted to the public sector as well as
            the private sector, and can cover a wide range of services.
            The challenge will be how to coordinate supply and demand
            side subsidies.
